value_flows.revenue_engine: Public Cloud Managed Services (Hyperscaler Resale + Management)
value_flows.flow_description: VALUE FLOW: (1) Customer decides to adopt/expand AWS/Azure/Google infrastructure → (2) Rackspace sales engages, conducts discovery, proposes solution architecture → (3) Solutions architect designs cloud environment (compute, storage, network, security) → (4) Delivery team provisions hyperscaler resources via APIs, configures monitoring/alerting, establishes support processes → (5) 24x7 operations team delivers ongoing management (monitoring, incident response, patching, optimization, architecture guidance) → (6) Monthly billing generated (hyperscaler infrastructure consumption at list rates + Rackspace management fee) → (7) Customer pays → (8) Rackspace receives payment. CRITICAL: Value is SPLIT - hyperscaler provides infrastructure (billed as pass-through), Rackspace provides human expertise layer (management fee). Customer perceives value as BUNDLED convenience (single vendor, single invoice, 'Fanatical Support').
value_flows.value_created_at: Value INITIATED by customer infrastructure need. Value CREATED by Rackspace at: (A) Architecture design (translating business requirements into cloud blueprint), (B) Ongoing operational management (keeping infrastructure running, optimized, secure without customer needing internal cloud expertise). Rackspace does NOT create infrastructure value (hyperscaler does) - Rackspace creates OPERATIONAL LEVERAGE value (customer avoids hiring/training internal cloud teams).
value_transformed_at: SALES-TO-DELIVERY HANDOFF: Customer requirements translated from business language (sales) into technical specifications (solutions architect). Knowledge transfer friction - if poorly documented, delivery team must re-discover requirements causing delays and errors.

ARCHITECTURE DESIGN: Customer generic 'I need cloud' becomes specific resource topology (VPCs, subnets, security groups, IAM policies, monitoring dashboards). Design quality determines ongoing operational cost and complexity. Bad design = permanent operational burden.

PROVISIONING: Infrastructure blueprint becomes live running environment. APIs automate but human validation required (security review, cost estimation, customer acceptance). Provisioning errors create rework loops.

STEADY-STATE OPERATIONS: Reactive monitoring/incident response transforms into proactive optimization recommendations. Customer relationship deepens - upsell opportunities emerge (migration of additional workloads, multi-cloud expansion). Value density INCREASES over time IF customer sticky.
value_flows.value_delivered_at: CONTINUOUS DELIVERY via 24x7 operations team: Real-time monitoring alerts catch infrastructure issues before customer impact, Incident response resolves problems (often before customer aware), Performance optimization reduces customer cloud costs or improves application speed, Architecture guidance enables customer to adopt new cloud services, Security monitoring detects threats. Delivery is PEOPLE-INTENSIVE - value delivered through human expertise, not automation. Customer perceives value through: uptime (no outages), responsiveness (fast ticket resolution), cost savings (optimization recommendations accepted), trust (certified cloud engineers available 24x7).
value_flows.value_realized_at: MONTHLY BILLING: Rackspace bills customer for: (1) Hyperscaler infrastructure consumption (AWS/Azure/Google charges at list rates, pass-through), (2) Management fee (percentage of infrastructure OR tiered flat fee: $50/mo Managed Infrastructure, $500/mo Managed Operations). REALIZATION FRICTION: If customer perceives low value from management layer (slow ticket response, no proactive optimization, generic support), they compare management fee to ZERO cost of hyperscaler-direct relationship. Month-to-month billing means customer can defect at any time. VALUE REALIZATION = customer renewal decision each month. Churn = value realization failed.
entities_and_functions_involved: SALES (distributed across US, UK, APAC): Enterprise account executives, inside sales, sales engineers. Compensated on bookings. Hand off to delivery after contract signed.

SOLUTIONS ARCHITECTS (certified AWS/Azure/Google professionals): Design cloud environments. Bridge sales and delivery. Typically involve pre-sales (free consulting to win deal) and post-sales (implementation).

DELIVERY OPERATIONS (24x7 NOC teams across time zones): Cloud engineers, system administrators. Monitor infrastructure, respond to incidents, execute change requests. Allocated by customer segment or technology (AWS vs Azure vs Google specialists).
CUSTOMER SUCCESS/ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT: Own renewal relationship, identify upsell opportunities, escalate issues. Bridge between delivery and customer business stakeholders.
BILLING/FINANCE: Generate invoices pulling hyperscaler consumption data + management fees. Reconcile hyperscaler bills. Collect payment.
HYPERSCALER RELATIONSHIPS (AWS/Azure/Google account managers): Provide technical support to Rackspace, manage partner credits/rebates, joint customer engagement for large deals.

ENTITIES: Revenue flows through Rackspace US, Inc. (US customers), Rackspace Singapore (APAC), Rackspace UK (UK commercial). Government Public Cloud likely separate but Stage 1 did not identify Public Cloud entity separation.
evidence_sources: Public Cloud revenue model: hyperscaler infrastructure pass-through + management fee per Stage 2.1
Rackspace website: Describes solutions architecture, 24x7 support, certified engineers as value proposition
Pricing documentation: Managed Infrastructure $50+, Managed Operations $500+ minimum monthly fees
Stage 2.2: Public Cloud delivery personnel costs (SEMI-FIXED) indicate people-intensive operations model
Month-to-month billing creates continuous renewal cycle per Stage 2.2
Stage 2.1: Public Cloud gross margin 10.4% indicates thin value capture, majority of revenue is hyperscaler pass-through

value_flows.revenue_engine: Private Cloud Managed Services (Dedicated Infrastructure + Management)
value_flows.flow_description: VALUE FLOW: (1) Customer requires dedicated infrastructure (compliance, performance isolation, customization) → (2) Rackspace sales engages, validates requirements, proposes Private Cloud solution → (3) Solutions architect designs dedicated environment (servers, storage, networking, virtualization platform - VMware/OpenStack/Microsoft) → (4) Procurement: Hardware ordered from vendors (Dell, HPE, etc.), data center capacity reserved → (5) Deployment: Infrastructure installed in Rackspace data center (or customer premises for colocation), racked/stacked, cabled, configured, tested → (6) Customer workloads migrated onto infrastructure (may take weeks-months for large environments) → (7) Steady-state operations: 24x7 management, patching, monitoring, capacity management → (8) Monthly billing: Fixed infrastructure fee + management fee → (9) Customer pays → (10) Rackspace receives payment. CRITICAL: Private Cloud has LONG LEAD TIME from sale to revenue (procurement + deployment = 4-12 weeks typical) and LARGE UPFRONT CAPEX (Rackspace purchases hardware before receiving customer payment). Value is delivered as DEDICATED CONTROL and WHITE-GLOVE SERVICE vs public cloud self-service.
value_flows.value_created_at: Value INITIATED by customer need for dedicated resources (cannot use multi-tenant public cloud due to: compliance requirements - FedRAMP, HIPAA, PCI, performance predictability - no noisy neighbors, customization - specific hardware/network config, data sovereignty - specific geography). Value CREATED by Rackspace at: (A) Infrastructure procurement and deployment (Rackspace absorbs CapEx risk and supply chain management), (B) Dedicated operations team (customer-specific configurations, white-glove SLAs, deep environment knowledge), (C) Ongoing capacity planning and hardware refresh (Rackspace manages infrastructure lifecycle). Customer avoids: upfront CapEx, data center facility costs, hardware vendor management, infrastructure expertise hiring.
value_transformed_at: SALES-TO-ARCHITECTURE: Customer business requirements (e.g., 'must meet HIPAA', 'need 10ms latency', 'process 1M transactions/day') translated into infrastructure specifications (CPU cores, RAM, storage IOPS, network bandwidth, redundancy design). Under-sizing = performance issues, over-sizing = wasted cost.

ARCHITECTURE-TO-PROCUREMENT: Technical specs become vendor purchase orders. Lead times vary by component (servers 2-4 weeks, specialized storage 6-8 weeks, networking gear 4-6 weeks). Supply chain delays propagate to customer go-live. CapEx committed BEFORE customer revenue.

PROCUREMENT-TO-DEPLOYMENT: Hardware arrives at data center, must be: racked (physical installation), powered/cooled (facilities provisioning), cabled (network connectivity), configured (OS, virtualization, storage), tested (burn-in, validation), documented (runbooks, procedures). DEPLOYMENT FRICTION: 2-4 week cycle from hardware arrival to customer-ready. Manual labor-intensive - requires data center techs, network engineers, systems engineers.

DEPLOYMENT-TO-MIGRATION: Customer workloads must be migrated from existing environment (on-premises, competitor, public cloud) to new Rackspace infrastructure. MIGRATION FRICTION: Application testing, data transfer (potentially TBs-PBs over WAN), cutover planning, rollback procedures. 20-30% of migrations experience problems (per Stage 1 integration risk benchmarks). Migration failure = revenue delay or customer loss.

STEADY-STATE OPERATIONS: Infrastructure stabilizes, operations team knowledge deepens about customer environment. Over time: incident response improves (faster MTTR), capacity planning optimizes (right-sizing), customer trust builds (renewal and expansion). Value density INCREASES but Private Cloud secular decline (13% YoY) suggests value perception losing to public cloud alternatives.
value_flows.value_delivered_at: CONTINUOUS DELIVERY via dedicated operations teams: 24x7 monitoring and alerting customized to customer environment, Proactive maintenance (patching, firmware updates, capacity additions) executed during customer-approved windows, Performance optimization for customer-specific workloads (database tuning, storage tiering, network optimization), Capacity planning and hardware refresh managed by Rackspace (customer avoids refresh cycles), White-glove support (dedicated account team, faster escalation, customer-specific runbooks). Delivery is INFRASTRUCTURE + PEOPLE - customer pays for both dedicated hardware and dedicated operational expertise. Customer perceives value through: reliability (uptime SLAs), performance (consistent latency/throughput), control (can request custom configurations), compliance (auditable isolated environment).
value_flows.value_realized_at: MONTHLY BILLING: Customer pays fixed monthly fee for: (1) Infrastructure footprint (number of servers, storage TBs, network bandwidth allocated), (2) Management tier (Managed Operations typical for Private Cloud, $500+ monthly minimum per Stage 2.1). REALIZATION WINDOW: Contract terms typically 12-36 months (longer than Public Cloud month-to-month) but declining 13% YoY indicates customers NOT RENEWING at end of term. VALUE REALIZATION FRICTION: Customer compares Private Cloud cost to public cloud alternatives and questions value premium. VMware cost increases (Broadcom 200-300%) may force Rackspace to raise prices, triggering churn. Customer perception: 'Why pay for dedicated infrastructure when AWS/Azure offer similar compliance, performance, and lower cost?' Value realization failing = Private Cloud secular decline.
entities_and_functions_involved: SALES (Enterprise-focused, longer sales cycles than Public Cloud): Sell against customer compliance requirements, legacy infrastructure refresh cycles, data sovereignty needs. Must understand customer regulatory/compliance landscape.

SOLUTIONS ARCHITECTS (Infrastructure specialists, VMware/storage/network certified): Design dedicated environments considering: sizing, redundancy, compliance requirements, integration with customer existing systems.

PROCUREMENT/SUPPLY CHAIN: Manage vendor relationships (Dell, HPE, Cisco, VMware), place purchase orders, track hardware deliveries, manage inventory. CRITICAL FRICTION: 6-12 week procurement cycle delays revenue realization.

DATA CENTER OPERATIONS (Rackspace-operated facilities or customer premises): Physical installation, racking/stacking, power/cooling provisioning, physical security. Facilities team separate from delivery operations team.

DEPLOYMENT ENGINEERS: Configure and test infrastructure pre-customer, execute customer migrations, hand off to operations team. Specialized skillset - mix of infrastructure knowledge and project management.

DELIVERY OPERATIONS (Dedicated customer teams, 24x7): Private Cloud requires DEDICATED engineers per customer (vs Public Cloud where engineers support multiple customers). Higher personnel cost per dollar of revenue. Teams specialized by platform: VMware team, OpenStack team, Microsoft Hyper-V team.
VENDOR MANAGEMENT (VMware/Broadcom, hardware vendors): Ongoing license renewals, support contracts, warranty claims. VMware relationship now FRICTION due to Broadcom price shock.

ENTITIES: Private Cloud revenue flows through: Rackspace US, Inc. (US commercial), Rackspace Government Solutions (FedRAMP-authorized, isolated), RACKSPACE LIMITED (UK Sovereign Services, architecturally isolated). Multi-entity structure per Stage 1 FRAGMENTS operations - cannot share infrastructure or personnel across entities.
evidence_sources: Private Cloud revenue model: dedicated infrastructure + management per Stage 2.1
Stage 2.2: Private Cloud fixed costs (infrastructure depreciation, facilities) indicate capital-intensive model with long asset life
CapEx $136M (2024) indicates ongoing infrastructure procurement for Private Cloud
Stage 1: Government requires isolated FedRAMP entity, UK Sovereign requires isolated UK infrastructure
Private Cloud declining 13% YoY per Stage 2.1 indicates value realization failing vs public cloud alternatives
Industry knowledge: Hardware procurement lead times 4-12 weeks, data center deployments 2-6 weeks
Stage 1.3: Customer migration failure rates 20-30% for infrastructure platforms

value_flows.revenue_engine: Government Managed Services (FedRAMP-Authorized) - Subset of Private Cloud
value_flows.flow_description: VALUE FLOW: (1) Federal agency identifies cloud infrastructure need that MUST be FedRAMP-authorized → (2) Agency issues RFP or conducts market research, identifies Rackspace as FedRAMP JAB P-ATO holder → (3) Rackspace Government Solutions sales team (security-cleared) engages, validates requirements against FedRAMP baseline, proposes solution → (4) Solutions architect designs environment within FedRAMP boundary (must use only authorized services, configurations, and personnel) → (5) Procurement: Hardware ordered, CONUS data center capacity allocated (infrastructure CANNOT leave US or be managed by non-US citizens per Stage 1) → (6) Deployment: Infrastructure installed in FedRAMP-authorized data center, configured per baseline security controls, tested for compliance → (7) ATO (Authority to Operate) process: Agency reviews Rackspace SSP (System Security Plan), conducts security assessment, grants ATO for specific workload on Rackspace infrastructure → (8) Workload migration onto FedRAMP infrastructure → (9) Ongoing operations: Continuous monitoring, vulnerability scanning, compliance reporting per FedRAMP requirements → (10) Monthly billing: Federal contract rates (typically higher than commercial due to compliance overhead) → (11) Agency pays via federal payment systems (slow - 30-60+ day payment terms typical) → (12) Rackspace receives payment. CRITICAL: Government revenue is ENTITY-LOCKED and COMPLIANCE-GATED. Cannot serve federal customers without FedRAMP authorization. Cannot deliver services using non-US personnel or offshore infrastructure.
value_flows.value_created_at: Value INITIATED by federal compliance mandate - agencies MUST use FedRAMP-authorized providers for cloud services (regulatory requirement, not customer choice). Value CREATED by Rackspace at: (A) FedRAMP authorization maintenance (Rackspace invests in continuous compliance - annual audits, vulnerability remediation, security control testing), (B) Security-cleared personnel (US citizens with background checks, dedicated to government business), (C) Isolated infrastructure (physically/logically separated from commercial to prevent data commingling), (D) Federal expertise (understanding agency requirements, contract vehicles like GSA schedules, federal procurement processes). Customer (agency) CANNOT use non-FedRAMP providers - Rackspace creates value by meeting mandatory baseline.
value_transformed_at: SALES-TO-COMPLIANCE: Agency RFP requirements (often 100+ pages of technical specs, security controls, contract terms) must be mapped to Rackspace FedRAMP capabilities. Compliance gap analysis - any missing controls must be implemented BEFORE bidding or noted as exception. Sales cycle 6-18 months typical for large federal deals.

ARCHITECTURE-TO-AUTHORIZATION: Technical design must satisfy BOTH customer requirements AND FedRAMP security controls (800+ control requirements). Design choices constrained - cannot use non-FedRAMP-authorized services, cannot store data outside CONUS, cannot use non-US personnel. Over-engineering required to pass security review.

DEPLOYMENT-TO-ATO: Infrastructure deployment does NOT equal customer go-live. Agency must conduct security assessment of Rackspace environment + specific workload configuration, which takes 3-12 months. ATO GATING: Customer CANNOT use infrastructure until ATO granted. Revenue delayed even after infrastructure operational.

OPERATIONS-TO-CONTINUOUS MONITORING: Government operations require ADDITIONAL overhead vs commercial: Continuous vulnerability scanning and remediation (findings must be fixed within defined timeframes or risk ATO revocation), Compliance reporting (monthly/quarterly reports to agency and JAB), Audit support (annual FedRAMP assessment + agency-specific audits), Incident response to government SOC (Security Operations Center). COMPLIANCE OVERHEAD is PERMANENT cost that cannot be eliminated.
value_flows.value_delivered_at: CONTINUOUS DELIVERY via security-cleared operations teams (US citizens in CONUS): FedRAMP-compliant infrastructure management (all security controls maintained), Vulnerability management (scan-patch-verify cycle within FedRAMP timelines), Compliance reporting (evidence generation for audits), Incident response (government-specific IR procedures, breach notification), Dedicated support (security-cleared account teams, faster escalation for mission-critical systems). Delivery is CONSTRAINED by: personnel requirements (US citizen hiring pool smaller, higher cost), infrastructure location (CONUS only, cannot offshore), process overhead (every change requires security impact analysis). Customer perceives value through: compliance (passes audits), assurance (isolated environment for sensitive data), support (dedicated cleared teams).
value_flows.value_realized_at: CONTRACT-BASED BILLING: Government customers typically on: GSA Schedule contracts (pre-negotiated rates, faster procurement), Agency-specific contracts (BPA - Blanket Purchase Agreement, IDIQ - Indefinite Delivery Indefinite Quantity), Task Orders against larger vehicles. Billing is: Federal contract rates (often 10-30% premium vs commercial due to compliance overhead and US personnel costs), Payment via federal systems (slow - 30-60+ day payment cycles, sometimes 90+ days), Contract modifications for changes (cannot quickly adjust scope/pricing like commercial month-to-month). VALUE REALIZATION FRICTION: Long sales cycles (6-18 months), ATO gating delays revenue, slow payment cycles, and change-of-control risk (foreign acquisition INVALIDATES FedRAMP, per Stage 1, causing immediate customer loss). Government revenue ONLY REALIZABLE by US-controlled entity with FedRAMP authorization.
entities_and_functions_involved: RACKSPACE GOVERNMENT SOLUTIONS entity (separate from commercial Rackspace US, Inc.): Holds FedRAMP JAB P-ATO, cannot be merged with commercial entity without losing authorization. Entity separation per Stage 1 is MANDATORY.

SECURITY-CLEARED SALES (US citizens with Secret/Top Secret clearances in some cases): Navigate federal procurement, respond to RFPs, build agency relationships. Separate sales team from commercial - cannot share leads or cross-sell easily due to clearance/expertise requirements.
SOLUTIONS ARCHITECTS (FedRAMP-certified, US citizens): Design within FedRAMP boundary constraints. Must understand both cloud architecture AND federal security controls (NIST 800-53).

COMPLIANCE TEAM (dedicated to government business): Maintain FedRAMP authorization (annual audits, POA&M management, continuous monitoring), support agency ATOs (provide SSP, evidence packages, assessment support), respond to audit findings.

OPERATIONS TEAM (100% US citizens in CONUS per Stage 1): Deliver services from US-based NOC. Cannot use offshore teams (India, LATAM) common in commercial operations. HIGHER LABOR COST due to US-only requirement.

FEDRAMP-AUTHORIZED DATA CENTERS (CONUS only): Infrastructure CANNOT be relocated outside US without losing FedRAMP authorization. Cannot share data centers with commercial customers (isolation requirement).

GOVERNMENT ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT: Dedicated cleared account teams manage relationships with >50% of federal cabinet agencies (per Stage 1). Long-term relationships critical - federal sales based on trust and track record.
